title: Police seek legal advice over Waylon Johncock who stoned a wombat to death in Eyre Peninsula
text:
An Aboriginal police officer could be facing criminal charges after he was caught stoning a wombat to death.

Police are seeking independent legal advice on how to prosecute Waylon Johncock after horrific footage went viral of him repeatedly throwing rocks at a wombat's head at South Australia's Eyre Peninsula, on October 3.

The reason to seek independent legal advice comes after 'complexity and issues involved in the case' sources told The Advertiser.

Police are seeking independent legal advice on how to prosecute Waylon Johncock after footage of him stoning a wombat went viral

The video was taken on South Australia's Eyre Peninsula, showing the off-duty officer repeatedly throwing rocks at the wombat's head while being encouraged by a friend

The inquiry was launched earlier this month with the final decision determining whether or not Johncock will face any criminal charges relating to animal cruelty.

Police declined to comment on the case due to the ongoing investigation.

The footage sparked outrage across the country, and Aboriginal elders came forward and slam the cop's actions.

Ngarrindjeri elder Major Sumner said the officer's shockingly cruel actions in stoning the gentle animal were 'wrong'.

'We didn't hunt like that. We still don't hunt like that,' the 71-year-old said.

The inquiry was launched earlier this month with the final decision determining whether or not Johncock will face any criminal charges relating to animal cruelty

Ngarrindjeri elder Major Sumner (pictured) said the officer's shocking cruel actions in stoning the gentle animal was 'wrong'

His comments come after Wirangu-Kokatha elder Jack Johncock said the cop was acting within his rights.

Under the Native Title Act of 1993, Aboriginal people are allowed to maintain ancient customs such as hunting local wildlife.

Indigenous people in South Australia have traditionally killed wombats with rocks.

'For the people of the west coast of South Australia, the wombat is a big part of their diet and they'll get wombat any way they can,' he said.

He said a petition to make killing with rocks illegal showed a 'lack of understanding of cultural practices'.

'Don't they think they've done enough changes in this country to take away all our rights and customs?' he said.

'I think enough is enough.

Jack said that people should not judge something that has been part of his culture for thousands of years.

Premier Steven Marshall described the video of the incident as 'gut-wrenching'.

'The public dissemination of acts which glorify cruelty to animals is completely and utterly unacceptable,' he said.

'Animal cruelty is animal cruelty.

'Most people looking at that footage would be disgusted.'

The video shows the wombat waddling along the road as two men in a car follow, before the Johncock steps out of the car wearing only shorts and shoes.

He starts chasing the animal before the man behind the wheel tells him to 'get up close'.

The video shows the wombat waddling along the road as two men in a car follow, before the Johncock steps out of the car wearing only shorts and shoes

Johncock is seen picking up a large rock and viciously throws it at the wombat's head as both men laugh.

The wombat starts running in an attempt to get away from the men before they both chase after him.

'You've got him, you've got him, hit him, hit him,' the man in the car can be heard saying as Johncock picks up another rock.

'Kill him!'

As the man behind the wheel speeds up to keep the headlights shining on him, Johncock gives a final blow causing it to topple over.

'Yeah! You did it!' the man in the car says.

'First man I've ever seen kill a wombat on foot, bro.'
description: Police are seeking legal advice on how to prosecute Waylon Johncock who was filmed stoning a wombat to death at South Australia's Eyre Peninsula, on October 3.
authors: Sahar Mourad For Daily Mail Australia
